DataElement.preferredName: Patient Corrected QT Interval Outcome Or Family Medical History Long QT Syndrome Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria Code Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The coded response as to whether a patient meets the criteria for enrolling onto a clinical study for questions related to QTc results of the patient or the patient's family medical history of a ventricular arrhythmia characterized by a long QT interval as outlined in the study protocol.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Patient Corrected QT Interval Outcome Or Family Medical History Long QT Syndrome Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary._The time interval between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave in the cardiac cycle as corrected with a non-specified correction formula._The result of an action._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions._A ventricular arrhythmia characterized by a long QT interval, and accompanied by syncopal episodes sometimes leading to sudden death due to paroxysmal ventricular arrhythmia. This arrhythmia is associated with a prolongation of repolarization following depolarization of the cardiac ventricles. The prolongation of the Q-T interval combined with torsades de pointes manifests as several different forms; some may be acquired or congenital; some may lead to serious arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death._Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.:The time interval between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave in the cardiac cycle as corrected with a non-specified correction formula.

Concepts.definition: A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.
The time interval between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave in the cardiac cycle as corrected with a non-specified correction formula.

Property.preferredName: Outcome Or Family Medical History Long QT Syndrome Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria
Property.preferredDefinition: The result of an action.:An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.:A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.:A ventricular arrhythmia characterized by a long QT interval, and accompanied by syncopal episodes sometimes leading to sudden death due to paroxysmal ventricular arrhythmia. This arrhythmia is associated with a prolongation of repolarization following depolarization of the cardiac ventricles. The prolongation of the Q-T interval combined with torsades de pointes manifests as several different forms; some may be acquired or congenital; some may lead to serious arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death.:Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Concepts.definition: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.

A ventricular arrhythmia characterized by a long QT interval, and accompanied by syncopal episodes sometimes leading to sudden death due to paroxysmal ventricular arrhythmia. This arrhythmia is associated with a prolongation of repolarization following depolarization of the cardiac ventricles. The prolongation of the Q-T interval combined with torsades de pointes manifests as several different forms; some may be acquired or congenital; some may lead to serious arrhythmia and sudden cardiac death.
Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Yes No Not Applicable Code Indicator
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Indicator to represent a response of Yes, No, or Not Applicable._The affirmative response to a question or activity._The non-affirmative response to a question._Determination that a value is not relevant in the current context._A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

Concepts.definition: Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question or activity.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Yes No Not Applicable Code Indicator
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question or activity.:The non-affirmative response to a question.:Determination that a value is not relevant in the current context.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.:An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

Concepts.definition: The affirmative response to a question.
The non-affirmative response to a question.
Determination of a value is not relevant in the current context.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Created to support Theradex design of CRFs for NCI CCR trials

ReferenceDocuments.name: Does patient have a QTc great
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a QTc greater than 470 msec or family history of long QT syndrome?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have Fridericia's corrected QT interval (QTcF) less than or equal to 450 msec or other factors that increase the risk of QT prolongation or arrhythmic events (e.g., heart failure, hypokalemia, family history of long QT interval syndrome)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a resting ECG with a QTc greater than or equal to 450 msec detected on 2 or more time points within a 2 hour period or family history of long QT syndrome?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have Fridericia's corrected QT interval (QTcF) greater than or equal to 450 msec or other factors that increase the risk of QT prolongation or arrhythmic events (e.g., heart failure, hypokalemia, family history of long QT interval syndrome)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 4
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a mean resting correct QTc interval using the Fridericia formula (QTcF) of greater than 470 msec (as calculated per institutional standards) obtained from 3 electrocardiograms (ECGs) 2-5 minutes apart at study entry, or congenital long QT syndrome?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 5
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a resting EKG with a QTc greater than or equal to  470 msec detected on 2 or more time points within a 2 hour period or family history of long QT syndrome?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 6
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a QTcF greater than 470 msec (on resting ECG) or family history of long QT syndrome?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 7
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a resting EKG with a QTc greater than 470 msec on 2 or more time points within a 24 hour period or family history of long QT syndrome?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 9
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have mean resting correct QT interval (QTc) greater than 470 msec on screening obtained from 3 electrocardiograms (ECGs) or factors that may increase the risk of QTc prolongation such as chronic hypokalaemia not correctable with supplements, congenital or familial long QT syndrome, or family history of unexplained sudden death under 40 years of age?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 8
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a resting EKG with a QTc greater than 470 msec or family history of long QT syndrome?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 10
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have any  factors that may increase the risk of QTc prolongation or risk of arrhythmic event such as heart failure, chronic hypokalaemia not correctable with supplements, congenital or familial long QT syndrome, or family history of unexplained sudden death under 40 years of age or any concomitant medications know to prolong QT interval?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 11
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have any  factors that may increase the risk of QTcF prolongation such as chronic hypokalaemia not correctable with supplements, congenital or familial long QT syndrome, or family history of unexplained sudden death under 40 years of age in first degree relatives or any concomitant medications known to prolong QT interval and cause Torsade de Pointes?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 12
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have any factors that may increase the risk of QTc prolongation such as chronic hypokalaemia not correctable with supplements, congenital or familial long QT syndrome, or family history of unexplained sudden death under 40 years of age in first degree relatives or any concomitant medications known to prolong QT interval and cause Torsade de Pointes (TdP)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 14
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have a prolonged QTc interval greater than 480 milliseconds or a history of congenital long QT syndrome or torsades de pointes?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 13
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have history of additional risk factors for TdP (e.g. heart failure, hypokalemia, family history of long QT Syndrome)?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Theradex - 15
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does patient have clinically significant ECG abnormality, including prolonged corrected QT (QTc) interval greater than 480 msec or history of risk factors for Torsade's de Pointes (TdP) (i.e. congestive heart failure, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, bradyarrhythmias, family history of long QT syndrome)?
